TextEquiv.Unicode: time hee wincke at and dissemble it.
Fire shall destroy both them & theirs:
& they themselves shall for ever burne
in hell, where nothing shall remayne
of them, but a reprochfull memorie.
For in the Revelation of our Lord Je
sus Christ to his apostle John we read:
And fire came downe from God out
of heaven, and devoured them, and
the Divell which deceived them was
cast into a lake of fire and brimstone,
where the beast and the false Prophet
shalbe tormented day and night for e
vermore Apoc. 20.
Furthermore all thinges else are
forbidden that doe incite or allure us
to unlawfull lustes, which baytes are
the over nice pranking and decking
the body, evill and wanton company,
gluttony, surfetting and drunkennes.
For Exechiel among the rest of his
Prophecies, sayeth: This was the ini
quitie of Sodome, pride, gluttonie, a
boundaunce of all thinges, and idle
nesse. Men are provoked to lust ey
ther by hearing or reading of disho
nest ditties, and bawdie ballads, or by
looking on or beholding wanton daun
ces, unseemely sightes, ribauld talke,
and filthy examples. They therefore
are by this lawe reproved, which
wincke at, or chearish, which are the
bawedes or bringers together of adul
terous persons. Unto the wicked the
Lorde in the Psalmes doth say: Why
doest thou take my covenaunt in thy
mouth, whereas thou hatest to be re
fourmed, and doest cast my words be
hind thee? when thou sawest a theefe,
thou consentedst unto him: and hast
been partaker with the adulterers, & c.
The just Lorde therefore doth punish
all these offences in wicked men, eve
rie one according to the greatnesse of
the sin. For some sins are farre more
heynous than other some are. Hee is

time hee wincke at and dissemble it. Fire shall destroy both them & theirs: & they themselves shall for ever burne in hell, where nothing shall remayne of them, but a reprochfull memorie. For in the Revelation of our Lord Je sus Christ to his apostle John we read: And fire came downe from God out of heaven, and devoured them, and the Divell which deceived them was cast into a lake of fire and brimstone, where the beast and the false Prophet shalbe tormented day and night for e vermore Apoc. 20. Furthermore all thinges else are forbidden that doe incite or allure us to unlawfull lustes, which baytes are the over nice pranking and decking the body, evill and wanton company, gluttony, surfetting and drunkennes. For Exechiel among the rest of his Prophecies, sayeth: This was the ini quitie of Sodome, pride, gluttonie, a boundaunce of all thinges, and idle nesse. Men are provoked to lust ey ther by hearing or reading of disho nest ditties, and bawdie ballads, or by looking on or beholding wanton daun ces, unseemely sightes, ribauld talke, and filthy examples. They therefore are by this lawe reproved, which wincke at, or chearish, which are the bawedes or bringers together of adul terous persons. Unto the wicked the Lorde in the Psalmes doth say: Why doest thou take my covenaunt in thy mouth, whereas thou hatest to be re fourmed, and doest cast my words be hind thee? when thou sawest a theefe, thou consentedst unto him: and hast been partaker with the adulterers, & c. The just Lorde therefore doth punish all these offences in wicked men, eve rie one according to the greatnesse of the sin. For some sins are farre more heynous than other some are. Hee is
an adulterer that in his minde doeth
lust after an other mans wife: but hee
sinneth more greevously, if hee inde
vour to finishe in deede his wicked
thought, hee offendeth yet more deepe
ly if hee doe the deede, and sinneth most
of all, if after once, hee fall unto it a
gaine. Likewise the adulterer sinneth,
so doth the bawde, and he also that up
holdeth his adulterie. The whore
monger sinneth deepely, but hee that
defileth himselfe with incest, sinneth
more greevously, and hee most hey
nously of all, that in medling with
beasts, comitteth filthy Sodomy. So
then in this 7. precept charge is given
for the maintenance of shamefastnes,
modestie, sobriety, temperancy, cha
stity, publike honestie, and true ho
linesse of soule and bodie. The next is
for me to say somewhat now touching
continencie.
By abstinence we refraine from o
ther mens goods, and take from no ma
the thing that is his. Some there are
that will have temperancie to extend
farther than continencie: for they wil
make the one to be but a part of the o
ther. I, in this treatise, doe simplye
make continencie the contrarie to in
temperancie or incontinencie. For
continency is a vertue or power of
the minde, received from the spirite of
God, which suppresseth affections, and
doth not in any wife permit unlawful
pleasures. This is conversant & doth
shew it selfe in the common and viual
talke of men, in pleasures that are al
lowed, in apparell, in buildings and
dwelling houses, in meate and drink,
and in other things also. I at this pre
sent will onely examine those poyntes
of continencie, which are already re
hearsed.
First of all it is required of us to
keepe in our tongue, and not to let it

an adulterer that in his minde doeth lust after an other mans wife: but hee sinneth more greevously, if hee inde vour to finishe in deede his wicked thought, hee offendeth yet more deepe ly if hee doe the deede, and sinneth most of all, if after once, hee fall unto it a gaine. Likewise the adulterer sinneth, so doth the bawde, and he also that up holdeth his adulterie. The whore monger sinneth deepely, but hee that defileth himselfe with incest, sinneth more greevously, and hee most hey nously of all, that in medling with beasts, comitteth filthy Sodomy. So then in this 7. precept charge is given for the maintenance of shamefastnes, modestie, sobriety, temperancy, cha stity, publike honestie, and true ho linesse of soule and bodie. The next is for me to say somewhat now touching continencie. By abstinence we refraine from o ther mens goods, and take from no ma the thing that is his. Some there are that will have temperancie to extend farther than continencie: for they wil make the one to be but a part of the o ther. I, in this treatise, doe simplye make continencie the contrarie to in temperancie or incontinencie. For continency is a vertue or power of the minde, received from the spirite of God, which suppresseth affections, and doth not in any wife permit unlawful pleasures. This is conversant & doth shew it selfe in the common and viual talke of men, in pleasures that are al lowed, in apparell, in buildings and dwelling houses, in meate and drink, and in other things also.
